0.text:
So far this war things had looked grim for
the Russians. They had unwillingly entered

4.text:
the war in the first place and the colossal
defeats at the battles of Tannenberg and Masurian

9.text:
lakes had convinced the German and Austro-Hungarian
armies that Russia’s army was both backward

14.text:
and incompetent, but beginning this week they
would learn that Russia was no pushover at

19.text: all and had two enviable assets- men and space.

29.text: I’m Indy Neidell. Welcome to the Great War.

31.text:
Last week we saw Antwerp fall to the Germans,
and the Belgians and the British retreated

35.text:
into Flanders to build their defenses and
try to prevent the Germans from pushing to

40.text:
the sea, while the French held the line further
south. In the East, the Austrians were under

45.text:
siege in their fortress at Przemysl awaiting
relief, the Russians further north were marching

50.text:
to positions to cross the Vistula and attack
Germany, and the Germans were now only 20

56.text:
Here was the general German plan in the east-
to strike, with Austrian help, at Warsaw and

62.text:
Ivangorod and outflank the Russian army there
while the Austrians were being relieved from

69.text:
The Russians, after weeks of disastrous marching
through the mud, had finally reached their

73.text:
crossing point, built a bridgehead, and began
to cross. The Germans reached Warsaw on October

79.text:
12th, but their attacks were thrown back and
there would be no outflanking. See, the Germans

85.text:
had seen the Russian march and its colossal
mismanagement and believed that Russia was

90.text:
weak around Warsaw, but what they didn’t
realize was that the Russians armies were

94.text:
arriving and entering the battle in sections,
and more and more of them were coming. So

99.text:
we see that before October 15th, the Germans
had the upper hand, but after that, not so

105.text:
much. Soon there was no prospect of German
General von Hindenburg getting a decisive

111.text:
victory in view of the seemingly endless Russian
reinforcements, now coming from central Asia

119.text:
It’s important to realize that by this point
there were actually four fronts in the east-

124.text:
German-Russian in East Prussia, German-Austrian-Russian
on the Vistula, Russia-Austrian on the San

130.text:
River, and Russian-Austrian in the Carpathians,
and the middle two of them were now a concerted

136.text:
So along the San River, the Austrians had
finally managed to break out, relieved by

142.text:
General Boroevic von Bonja on October 11th.
This was timed to coincide with Hindenburg’s

148.text: German advances toward Warsaw further north.

151.text:
Boroevic, eventually a Field Marshall, was
a brilliant defensive strategist who later

156.text:
showed what he could do on the Italian front,
but for now he had to deal with his chief

161.text:
of Staff Conrad von Hotzendorf. section deleted
Conrad thought that the combined forces of

166.text:
the Austrians from within Przemysl and Boroevic’s
relief army could beat the Russians, so on

172.text:
October 14th, he ordered his men to try and
cross the San river and engage the enemy.

177.text:
It was a catastrophe, his men were bombarded
not only by the Russians but by their own

183.text:
side because of miscommunications and there
were no pontoons to make bridges, so they

187.text:
had to use boats to ferry themselves over,
and since one of the Austrian commanders thought

192.text:
a marching band might improve morale, he had
one playing on the Austrian shore. Imagine

199.text:
being one of those poor Austrian soldiers;
trying to cross a river in a boat while being

204.text:
bombarded by both the enemy and your own men,
your comrades are dying around you by the

209.text:
dozen while a marching band on the shore plays
“inspiring” music for you. It was truly

216.text:
So now that we’ve imagined being an Austrian
soldier, lets imagine that we live in Poland

224.text:
The Germans march in, then the Russians, sometimes
the Austrian[n][o]s, then the Germans again,

229.text:
back and forth and up and down- by now the
basic situation in the towns of Russian Poland

234.text:
was total anarchy. At least the German officers
had some training in civic leadership which

239.text:
their Russian counterparts lacked completely.
There sprang up a huge black market in this

245.text:
region for liquor and food, as you may guess,
but also weapons, uniforms, anything that

251.text:
the locals could scavenge from a battlefield,
or sadly, get from a soldier in exchange for

256.text:
food- even winter clothes with winter soon
here. Really, the troops were so desperate

262.text:
for food they were selling their winter boots,
knowing that Russian winter was coming in

269.text:
Another effect of anarchy in Russian Poland
was that when the German troops arrived, the

273.text:
local populations often turned against the
Jews, claiming they were secretly sympathetic

278.text:
to the German cause, and they began a series
of atrocities against them. Shops and synagogues

284.text:
were looted and burned, and Jews were hanged
every day. The idea that Jews were sympathetic

290.text:
to the German cause totally ignored the fact
that a quarter of a million Jews were serving

296.text: in the Russian army at the time.

298.text:
And that army was finally beginning to turn
itself around, not only because of its enormous

303.text:
size, but because Russia had a way of approaching
battle that none of the other combatants had.

309.text:
See, Russia had no problem giving up land
to the enemy and using space to fight a war

314.text:
instead of just force. This had always held
true- think of Napoleon marching on Russia

320.text:
100 years ago and the disaster it ended in
for him. Russia had thousands upon thousands

326.text:
of miles of land and if the enemy made some
gains, or even took a whole province- so what?

332.text:
It would simply be re-taken when the enemy
stretched itself too thin and became exhausted.

338.text:
And how does an enemy counter this when the
enemy can’t think like that?

342.text:
None of the other armies had that luxury.
It was immoral for the Germans to cede any

347.text:
of East Prussia to Russia, it was humiliating
to the Austrians that Russia now held Austrian

353.text:
ground and cities, and it was absolutely unthinkable
for the Belgians and French to give up an

358.text:
inch of their land to the Germans in the west,
where the war for a decisive victory was now

364.text: a war for roads, villages, and hills.

367.text:
The Race to the sea had been going on for
weeks as the Germans tried to outflank the

371.text:
British, French, and Belgians, and vice versa.
The trench lines grew ever longer as neither

376.text:
side was able to gain an advantage and both
sides were forced to dig in.

381.text:
Battles that would rage for weeks began in
places like La Bassee, Armentieres, and Messines

387.text:
as the line grew further and further north.
On the 11th, the Germans began bombarding

392.text:
Lille, which surrendered on the 13th and would
remain in German hands for the next four years.

397.text:
This part of France and Belgium, called Flanders,
was still mostly untouched by the war, and

402.text:
when on October 14th, some British forces
entered the town of Ypres, it seemed like

408.text:
a nice quiet country town. They promptly began
calling it Wipers.

412.text:
The next day they marched east a few miles
and made preparations to make a quick advance

417.text:
on the Germans as soon as the rest of the
British expeditionary Force turned up. No

422.text:
one realized yet that this quaint little patch
of Belgian countryside would soon become the

427.text:
gravesite for over 200,000 British soldiers
during the next four years.

433.text:
British soldiers were going to a watery grave
this week as well, as the German submarine

437.text:
U-9, already infamous for dispatching three
British cruisers in one hour, torpedoed the

443.text:
Hawke in the north sea- 525 British sailors
drowned. Only 21 were saved.

449.text:
However, as the war in the seas grew and developed,
the British gained a lucky advantage. Russia

455.text:
sent them a German navy signal book it had
captured when the German signalman about to

460.text:
destroy it was killed by an artillery shell.
Because of this, British cryptographers in

465.text:
future had a leg up decoding wireless messages
and finding their adversaries at sea.

470.text:
So there we are at the end of the week, with
the British arriving at a nice quiet town

474.text:
called Ypres at the northern end of the miles
and miles of trenches, the Austrians sinking

479.text:
into despair as their maneuvers once again
prove disastrous, the Germans realizing that

484.text:
Russia was nowhere near as incompetent as
they’d thought, and the Russians bringing

489.text:
more, and more, and ever more men to bear
down on the Germans along the Vistula River.

496.text:
Germany and Austria knew, of course, that
Russia had the population advantage, but they’d

500.text:
gone to war confident that their advantages
in tactics and equipment would more than make

506.text:
up for this. And for the Germans, at least,
so far it had. But nobody quite realized the

511.text:
depth of the Russian reinforcements and as
the enemy army’s initial forces were depleted,

517.text:
that depth, as well as the use of the endless
open space, had finally made the Russian army

523.text:
a real force to be reckoned with, and over
the next two months, hundreds of thousands

527.text:
of men would die on the enormous battlefields
of the Eastern Front.

532.text:
If you’d like to see how trench warfare
developed in this war, check out these episodes

536.text:
about the battles on the banks of the Aisne
River, and click subscribe to never miss an

540.text: episode. For the next four years.
